addressleaf.section:
To
e right honorable my very singular good Lord,
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

31 Au
g
1591. M
r
Bodley from the Haghe
The Enterprise of
Stenwyck
misliked.

page.lettertext:
fol.349r
It may please yo
r
good L. to be advertised,
at
the resolution of
e
states,
for
e order of their
trafficke, is sent to
M
r
Caron
, w
t
a letter to
her
Ma
tie
w
ch
they caused this morning to be
signified unto me. The forces of
these contreis continue still in garrison, and
there is nothing yet concluded about their
imploiment. Those of
Guelders
and
Utrecht
would have them returned to
e siege of
Nieu-
meghen
:
e
states of Friseland
are earnest
for steenwicke:
Holland
for
Boisleduke,
and
Zeland
for
Hulst,
w
ch
was
e enterprise in-
tended, when
e army was dissolved, and
hath depended ever sins, till certaine Captaines
shall returne, whome
e Count hath imploied, to
take a viewe of
e contrey. It is thought
e
attempt of Steenwicke would prove over costly,
because
e towne hath bin fortified, sins
e shewe
that was made to besiege it this sommer. It
hath besides in garrison 1200 souldiers.
Ether Nieumeghen, or Boisleduke, might be got-
ten more easely, if
e Enemies forces were
further removed: and we can not yet sur-
mise, for what occasion they should linger so
long in a place. We are newly nowe ad-
vertised,
at they marche to
Mastricht,
and
that
e
Duke
is still at
Brussels.
Wheras yo
r
L. hath required me of late, to
doe some good for
M
r
Winter
, I have caused
Don Alfonso
, and
Pedro Francesco
, to write unto
their frindes, to solicit his deliverance: w
ch
they
doe, as they seeme, very willingly and earnestly.
fol.349v
For I have thus agreed w
t
them bothe, w
t
the
privitie and liking of M
r
Winters servant,
That although they be men of greater account,
in respect of their experience and service in
e warres, then M
r
Winter, yet in procuring
him to be presently released, they shall bothe be
sette at libertie, w
t
out paieng any raunsome.
For a farre lesser summe, then I perceave M
r
Winter would disbourse to be delivered, will
content
e Captaines of this contrey, for
e fore-
said prisoners. And I hold my self assured,
that Count Maurice in that will take a favo-
rable order. I am
e lesse out of hope of good
successe in this mater, because Alfonso, I heare,
is neere of kinne to
e Duke of Parma: and
e
other, it is knowen, hath served
e Duke these
22 yeres: and did governe him greatly in
all his exploites, as no man more about him.
It is all my feare, w
ch
is also theirs, as they
signifie unto me, that
Mondragon
a spaniard,
and an enemie to their nation, will nether
make any reckning of them, nor of any thing
e Duke shall request in their behalf.
And
thus I take my humble leave. At
e Hage.
Au
g
31 1591.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley.
